resource.chars:
[equations not transcribed]
In the solution usually given of these equations,
u is expressed in a series of <u>cosines<\u> of angles composed of multiples 
of 2v-2mv, cv-[omega], & c’mv-[omega]’; <s>and t<\s> Also t is expressed in terms of v &
a series of <u>sines <\u> of the same angles; the coefficients 
of these periodic terms being functions of m, e & e’.
Now if e’ be a constant quantity, this is the 
true form of the solution, but if e’ be variable,
it is impossible to satisfy the differential equations 
without adding to the expression for u a series of 
small supplementary terms depending on the <u>sines<\u>,
of the angles whose cosines are already involved in it & to that for t, similar terms depending on the 
<u>cosines<\u> of the same angles; <s>already involved<\u> the coefficients of these new terms 
involving de’/dt as a factor.
These terms, though quite insensible in themselves, 
give rise to that modification of the moon’s secular 
acceleration which is the object of the present
investigation, & we must therefore commence by
